## Open Source > Closed Source

 - Pro
    - Often as good, or better than closed source
    - Avoid getting locked into proprietary formats
    - No License

- Con
    - Can demand a bit more involvement to set up
    - Can become abandonware

::: { .notes }



:::

## Voyant

> see through your text

[![Voyant- Austen](/assets/Voyant.jpg){fig-align="center" width="80%"}](https://voyant-tools.org/?corpus=austen)

![](https://voyant-tools.org/resources/images/voyant-see.png){.absolute bottom=-10 right=-20 height="60px"}

::: { .notes }

Voyant is a good entrypoint into computational text-analysis.

Can be run for free (with some size limitation) on their servers.

Can also be installed to run locally, which is a good option when you need to control the data

Many visualisation options for the various descriptive options

Good, solid documentation

(Topic Modeling)

:::


## Antconc

[![Antconc](https://www.laurenceanthony.net/software/antconc/screenshots/kwic.png){fig-align="center" width="80%"}](https://www.laurenceanthony.net/software/antconc/)

![](https://www.laurenceanthony.net/software/antconc/icons/AntConc.png){.absolute bottom=-10 right=-20 height="60px"}

::: { .notes }

Good entrypoint into corpus linguistics

((The screenshot shows KWIC: *Key Word In Context*))

:::

## Palladio

> Visualize complex historical data with ease

[![Palladio](/assets/Palladio.jpg){fig-align="center" width="80%"}](http://hdlab.stanford.edu/palladio/)


![](http://hdlab.stanford.edu/palladio/public/apple-touch-icon-120x120.png){.absolute bottom=-10 right=-20 height="60px"}

::: { .notes }

Produced, maintaned and hosted by Stanford

Highly interactive plotting tools for:
    GIS
    Networks
    Timelines

Supports 'complex' data

Good documentation

:::

## Gephi { .smaller }

> makes graphs handy

[![Palladio](https://gephi.org/images/screenshots/preview1.png){fig-align="center" width="70%"}](https://gephi.org/)

![](https://gephi.org/images/logo.png){.absolute bottom=-10 right=-20 height="60px"}

::: { .notes }

Network analysis tool with a low threshold

Supports simple and dynamic visualisations

This is the software *we* -- DigitalHistory@Lund -- are using during our *Working Groups*

:::

## QGIS { .smaller }

> A Free and Open Source Geographic Information System

[![QGIS](https://qgis.org/en/_static/images/about-screenshot.png){fig-align="center" width="70%"}](https://qgis.org/)

GIS software

## StoryToolkitAI { .smaller }

> tool that understands your footage and helps you edit more efficiently

[![StoryToolkitAI](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/octimot/StoryToolkitAI/main/help/storytoolkitai_v0.19.0.png){fig-align="center" height="80%"}](https://github.com/octimot/StoryToolkitAI)

::: { .notes }

Audio transcription tool

Runs locally

Can deal  with dialects and/or low sound quality with a very high level of accuracy

:::
